code_General.modelFiles.apiTokenModel¶

Generic Backend

Silvio Weging 2024

Contains: Model for all api tokens

Could have used the drf variant but would then have to use django admin and user accounts as well which sucks because we already have an ID Manager (auth0)

Classes¶

APITokenDescription

The model consists of the following:

APIToken

Management class for API Tokens.

class code_General.modelFiles.apiTokenModel.APIToken(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: django.db.models.Model

Management class for API Tokens.

User:

User linked to that token…

Organization:

… or organization linked to that token

Admin:

Boolean whether the user is an admin or not

Token:

Created url friendly token for that user

CreatedWhen:

Automatically assigned date and time(UTC+0) when the entry is created

createdWhen¶
save(*args, **kwargs)¶

Save the current instance. Override this in a subclass if you want to control the saving process.

The ‘force_insert’ and ‘force_update’ parameters can be used to insist that the “save” must be an SQL insert or update (or equivalent for non-SQL backends), respectively. Normally, they should not be set.
